chapter: 1 About
heading: 1 About
text: sample book written Markdown. can use anything Pandoc’s Markdown supports; example, math equation \(^2 + b^2 = c^2\).

chapter: 1 About
heading: 1.1 Usage
text: bookdown chapter .Rmd file, .Rmd file can contain one (one) chapter. chapter must start first-level heading: # good chapter, can contain one (one) first-level heading.Use second-level higher headings within chapters like: ## short section ### even shorter section.index.Rmd file required, also first book chapter. homepage render book.

chapter: 1 About
heading: 1.2 Render book
text: can render HTML version example book without changing anything:Find Build pane RStudio IDE, andFind Build pane RStudio IDE, andClick Build Book, select output format, select “formats” ’d like use multiple formats book source files.Click Build Book, select output format, select “formats” ’d like use multiple formats book source files.build book R console:render example PDF bookdown::pdf_book, ’ll need install XeLaTeX. recommended install TinyTeX (includes XeLaTeX): https://yihui.org/tinytex/.
code: bookdown::render_book()

chapter: 1 About
heading: 1.3 Preview book
text: work, may start local server live preview HTML book. preview update edit book save individual .Rmd files. can start server work session using RStudio add-“Preview book,” R console:
code: bookdown::serve_book()

chapter: 2 Hello bookdown
heading: 2 Hello bookdown
text: chapters start first-level heading followed chapter title, like line . one first-level heading (#) per .Rmd file.

chapter: 2 Hello bookdown
heading: 2.1 A section
text: chapter sections start second-level (##) higher heading followed section title, like sections . can many want within chapter.

chapter: 2 Hello bookdown
heading: An unnumbered section
text: Chapters sections numbered default. un-number heading, add {.unnumbered} shorter {-} end heading, like section.

chapter: 3 Cross-references
heading: 3 Cross-references
text: Cross-references make easier readers find link elements book.

chapter: 3 Cross-references
heading: 3.1 Chapters and sub-chapters
text:
two steps cross-reference heading:Label heading: # Hello world {#nice-label}.
Leave label like automated heading generated based heading title: example, # Hello world = # Hello world {#hello-world}.
label un-numbered heading, use: # Hello world {-#nice-label} {# Hello world .unnumbered}.
Leave label like automated heading generated based heading title: example, # Hello world = # Hello world {#hello-world}.label un-numbered heading, use: # Hello world {-#nice-label} {# Hello world .unnumbered}.Next, reference labeled heading anywhere text using \@ref(nice-label); example, please see Chapter 3.
prefer text link instead numbered reference use: text want can go .
prefer text link instead numbered reference use: text want can go .

chapter: 3 Cross-references
heading: 3.2 Captioned figures and tables
text:
Figures tables captions can also cross-referenced elsewhere book using \@ref(fig:chunk-label) \@ref(tab:chunk-label), respectively.See Figure 3.1.
Figure 3.1: nice figure!
Don’t miss Table 3.1.Table 3.1: nice table!
code:
par(mar = c(4, 4, .1, .1))
plot(pressure, type = 'b', pch = 19)
knitr::kable(
  head(pressure, 10), caption = 'Here is a nice table!',
  booktabs = TRUE
)

chapter: 4 Parts
heading: 4 Parts
text: can add parts organize one book chapters together. Parts can inserted top .Rmd file, first-level chapter heading file.Add numbered part: # (PART) Act one {-} (followed # chapter)Add unnumbered part: # (PART\*) Act one {-} (followed # chapter)Add appendix special kind un-numbered part: # (APPENDIX) stuff {-} (followed # chapter). Chapters appendix prepended letters instead numbers.

chapter: 5 Footnotes and citations
heading: 5.2 Citations
text:
Reference items bibliography file(s) using @key.example, using bookdown package2 (check last code chunk index.Rmd see citation key added) sample book, built top R Markdown knitr3 (citation added manually external file book.bib).
Note .bib files need listed index.Rmd YAML bibliography key.bs4_book theme makes footnotes appear inline click . example book, added csl: chicago-fullnote-bibliography.csl index.Rmd YAML, include .csl file. download new style, recommend: https://www.zotero.org/styles/RStudio Visual Markdown Editor can also make easier insert citations: https://rstudio.github.io/visual-markdown-editing/#/citations

chapter: 8 Alpha and Beta in Hypothesis Testing
heading: 8 Alpha and Beta in Hypothesis Testing

chapter: 8 Alpha and Beta in Hypothesis Testing
heading: 8.1 1. Examples of H0 and H1
text: H0: Age correlate frequency drinking soda.H1: Age correlate frequency drinking soda.

chapter: 8 Alpha and Beta in Hypothesis Testing
heading: 8.2 2. Definitions of Alpha and Beta
text: \(\alpha\) = probability Type error, known “false positive”\(\beta\) = probability Type II error, known “false negative”Accordingly,\(1-\alpha\) = “true negative,” .e., correctly rejecting null hypothesis\(1-\beta\) = “true positive,” .e., correctly rejecting null hypothesisNote , \(1-\beta\) another name, called power, statistical power.

chapter: 8 Alpha and Beta in Hypothesis Testing
heading: 8.3 3. Common Values of Alpha and Beta
text: Alpha (\(\alpha\)): Common choices \(\alpha\) 0.05, 0.01, 0.10. 5% significance level (\(\alpha\) = 0.05) frequently used many fields.commonly used power level (\(1-\beta\)) 0.80, meaning want 80% chance correctly rejecting false null hypothesis.

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.1 Effect size - Cohen’s
text: Cohen  used quantify size difference two groups, taking account variability within group.\[d = \frac{m_2 -m_1}{s_{pooled}}=\frac{m_2 -m_1}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2+s_2^2}{2}}}\]\(s_1\) sample standard deviation group 1, whereas \(s_2\) sample standard deviation group 2.

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.2 Effect Size - Pearson Product Moment
text: Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient, often referred Pearson correlation coefficient, quantifies strength linear relationship two variables.\[r_{xy} =\frac{cov(x,y)}{s_xs_y}=\frac{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})^2}\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (y_i-\bar{y})^2}}\]

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.3 Cohen’s  and Pearson’s
text: following effect size numbers based Jacob Cohen. ()

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.3.1 Comments
text: Cohen’s  can assume values ranging 0 infinity (.e., can greater 1), whereas Pearson’s  confined range -1 1.Note , based best understanding (sure), Cohen’s  can negative well, depending define \(m_1\) \(m_2\) order put .

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.3.2 Convert  to , and vice versa
text: Cohen’s  looks different Pearson’s , internal connection two.Group 1 group 2 may considered dichotomy two point scale.Thus, can convert  , vice versa.

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.3.3 Convert  to

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.3.4 Convert  to
text:
\[d^2=\frac{4r^2}{1-r^2}\]\[d^2=4r^2+r^2d^2=r^2(4+d^2)\]
\[r^2=\frac{d^2}{4+d^2}\]
\[r=\frac{d}{\sqrt{4+d^2}}\]According Cohen, sometimes, people might want think effect sizes mean differences  terms . Thus, can convert   needed.instance, group 1 group 2 two experimental manipulations. effect size typically . can convert .provide data demonstrate connection  .

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.4 Simulate both X and Y that are numerical
code:
# set the seed for reproducibility
set.seed(123)

# specify marginal means and standard deviations
mean_x <- 5
mean_y <- 6
sd_x <- 12
sd_y<- 14

## specify coefficient, which must be between -1 and 1
corcoef <- 0.5

## covariance between two variables
covariance <- corcoef * sd_x * sd_y

## variance-covariance matrix
sigma <- matrix(c(sd_x^2, covariance, covariance, sd_y^2), nrow = 2)

xy <- MASS::mvrnorm(n = 50, mu = c(mean_x, mean_y), Sigma = sigma)
colnames(xy) <- c("x", "y")
df <- data.frame(xy)
head(df)##           x          y
## 1 -2.188776  0.1167428
## 2  3.014416  2.8711033
## 3 20.168055 25.9184510
## 4 -4.307292 14.2689957
## 5  7.878421  6.4575243
## 6 10.288163 36.3225845
# plot it
plot(df)
abline(lm(y ~ x,data=df), col = "red")
cor.test(df$x,df$y)## 
##  Pearson's product-moment correlation
## 
## data:  df$x and df$y
## t = 4.2497, df = 48, p-value = 9.8e-05
## alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0
## 95 percent confidence interval:
##  0.2861663 0.6994209
## sample estimates:
##       cor 
## 0.5228658

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.5  vs. : Difference and Connection

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.6 Method 1: Direct Calculating
text: Since got column dichotomized x, can actually use formula mentioned calculate Cohen’s . , calculate means groups 1 2. , calculate sample standard deviations.\[d = \frac{m_2 -m_1}{s_{pooled}}=\frac{m_2 -m_1}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2+s_2^2}{2}}}\]
code:
# calculate group means
means<-aggregate(df$y, list(df$dichotomized_x), FUN=mean) 

# calculate sample standard deviation - pooled 
variances<- aggregate(df$y, list(df$dichotomized_x),FUN=var)
s_pooled=sqrt((variances$x[1]+variances$x[2])/2)

d_calculated<-(means$x[2]-means$x[1])/s_pooled
print(d_calculated)## [1] 1.252203

chapter: 9 Comparing Cohen d and Pearson r
heading: 9.7 Method 2: Converting  to
code:
# check the correlation coefficient
cor_result<-cor.test(df$x,df$y)
correlation_coefficient<-cor_result$estimate
d_converted<-2*correlation_coefficient/sqrt(1-correlation_coefficient^2)
print(d_converted)##      cor 
## 1.226787

chapter: 11 Q1: What is the use case of effect size?
heading: 11 Q1: What is the use case of effect size?
text: Effect size can used decide sample size.effect size decreases, need larger sample size increases.Effect size = 0.40Effect size = 0.30Changing effect size 0.4 0.3, required sample size increases 99 135.
code:
library(pwr)
pwr.t.test(n=NULL,
           d = 0.4,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = 0.80, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")## 
##      Two-sample t test power calculation 
## 
##               n = 99.08032
##               d = 0.4
##       sig.level = 0.05
##           power = 0.8
##     alternative = two.sided
## 
## NOTE: n is number in *each* group
pwr.t.test(n=NULL,
           d = 0.3,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = 0.80, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")## 
##      Two-sample t test power calculation 
## 
##               n = 175.3847
##               d = 0.3
##       sig.level = 0.05
##           power = 0.8
##     alternative = two.sided
## 
## NOTE: n is number in *each* group

chapter: 12 Q2: For effect size, any difference between correlation and linear regression?
heading: 12 Q2: For effect size, any difference between correlation and linear regression?

chapter: 12 Q2: For effect size, any difference between correlation and linear regression?
heading: 12.0.1 1. Theoretical part
text: Correlation:\[r_{xy} =\frac{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})^2}\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (y_i-\bar{y})^2}}\]Estimated slope simple linear regression:\[\hat{b} =\frac{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})^2}\]Standardized regression coefficient:\[\hat{\beta}=\hat{b}\frac{s_x}{s_y}=\frac{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})^2} \frac{\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})^2}}{\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (y_i-\bar{y})^2}}=\frac{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})^2}\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (y_i-\bar{y})^2}}\]Thus, correlation coefficient equal standardized regression coefficient X Y simple linear regressions (.e., regression model one X one Y).

chapter: 12 Q2: For effect size, any difference between correlation and linear regression?
heading: 12.0.2 2. Simulate a data for correlation / simple linear regression
code:
# set the seed for reproducibility
set.seed(123)

# specify marginal means and standard deviations
mean_x <- 5
mean_y <- 6
sd_x <- 12
sd_y<- 14

## specify coefficient, which must be between -1 and 1
corcoef <- 0.5

## covariance between two variables
covariance <- corcoef * sd_x * sd_y

## variance-covariance matrix
sigma <- matrix(c(sd_x^2, covariance, covariance, sd_y^2), nrow = 2)

xy <- MASS::mvrnorm(n = 50, mu = c(mean_x, mean_y), Sigma = sigma)
colnames(xy) <- c("x", "y")
df <- data.frame(xy)
head(df)##           x          y
## 1 -2.188776  0.1167428
## 2  3.014416  2.8711033
## 3 20.168055 25.9184510
## 4 -4.307292 14.2689957
## 5  7.878421  6.4575243
## 6 10.288163 36.3225845
# check the means
sapply(df, mean) ##        x        y 
## 4.260339 7.231809
# check the standard deviation
sapply(df, sd)  ##        x        y 
## 11.20860 12.75766
# plot it
plot(df)
abline(lm(y ~ x,data=df), col = "red")

chapter: 12 Q2: For effect size, any difference between correlation and linear regression?
heading: 12.0.4 Simple linear regression
code:
# simple linear regression
#raw x and y
lm(y ~ x,data=df)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = y ~ x, data = df)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)            x  
##      4.6964       0.5951
# simple linear regression
#standardized both x and y
lm(scale(y) ~ scale(x),data=df)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = scale(y) ~ scale(x), data = df)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)     scale(x)  
##  -2.463e-17    5.229e-01

chapter: 13 Q3: Why is  different from ?
heading: 13 Q3: Why is  different from ?
text: Since got column dichotomized x, can actually use formula mentioned calculate Cohen’s . , can calculate means groups 1 2. , can calculate sample standard deviations.\[d = \frac{m_2 -m_1}{s_{pooled}}=\frac{m_2 -m_1}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2+s_2^2}{2}}}\]\[d=\frac{2r}{\sqrt{1-r^2}}\]
code:
# dichotomize x
df$dichotomized_x<- ifelse(df$x >mean(df$x), 1, 0)
head(df)##           x          y dichotomized_x
## 1 -2.188776  0.1167428              0
## 2  3.014416  2.8711033              0
## 3 20.168055 25.9184510              1
## 4 -4.307292 14.2689957              0
## 5  7.878421  6.4575243              1
## 6 10.288163 36.3225845              1
# calculate group means
means<-aggregate(df$y, list(df$dichotomized_x), FUN=mean) 

# calculate sample standard deviation - pooled 
variances<- aggregate(df$y, list(df$dichotomized_x),FUN=var)
s_pooled=sqrt((variances$x[1]+variances$x[2])/2)

d_calculated<-(means$x[2]-means$x[1])/s_pooled
print(d_calculated)## [1] 1.252203
# check the correlation coefficient
cor_result<-cor.test(df$x,df$y)
correlation_coefficient<-cor_result$estimate
d_converted<-2*correlation_coefficient/sqrt(1-correlation_coefficient^2)
print(d_converted)##      cor 
## 1.226787

chapter: 15 How Effect Size Impact Sample Size
heading: 15.2 Effect Size and Sample Size
text: general, effect size increases, required sample size decreases, assuming statistical power (1 - \(\beta\)) alpha level (\(\alpha\)) held constant, respectively.

chapter: 15 How Effect Size Impact Sample Size
heading: 15.3 R Code Example 1: t-test
text: calculate needed sample size two-sample t-test specified power 0.8, significance level 0.05, effect size 0.5, can use pwr.t.test function R.

chapter: 15 How Effect Size Impact Sample Size
heading: 15.4 effect size = 0.50
text: Increasing effect size 0.5 0.8:
code:
# A simple way of writing the R code
library(pwr)
pwr.t.test(n=NULL,
           d = 0.5,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = 0.80, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")## 
##      Two-sample t test power calculation 
## 
##               n = 63.76561
##               d = 0.5
##       sig.level = 0.05
##           power = 0.8
##     alternative = two.sided
## 
## NOTE: n is number in *each* group

chapter: 15 How Effect Size Impact Sample Size
heading: 15.8 effect size = 0.50
code:
# A simple way of writing the R code

pwr.r.test(n = NULL, 
           r = 0.5, 
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = 0.80,
           alternative = "two.sided")## 
##      approximate correlation power calculation (arctangh transformation) 
## 
##               n = 28.24841
##               r = 0.5
##       sig.level = 0.05
##           power = 0.8
##     alternative = two.sided

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
text: following effect size numbers based Jacob Cohen’s  (Second Edition, p. 82)

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.0.1 Cohen’s
text: Cohen  used quantify size difference two groups, taking account variability within group.,  categorical variable, whereas  numerical variable (.e., Y continuous scale).\[d = \frac{m_2 -m_1}{s_{pooled}}=\frac{m_2 -m_1}{\sqrt{\frac{s_1^2+s_2^2}{2}}}\]

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.0.2 Pearson
text: numerical, need use pearson correlation coefficient measure effect size .\[r_{xy} =\frac{cov(x,y)}{s_xs_y}=\frac{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (x_i-\bar{x})^2}\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^n (y_i-\bar{y})^2}}\]

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.0.3 Convert  to

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.0.4 Convert  to
text: \[r=\frac{d}{\sqrt{d+d^2}}\]

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.1 Effect Size and Sample Size
text: Sample size number observations study.general, effect size decreases, larger sample size required, assuming power alpha held constant 0.8 0.05, respectively.

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.2 R Code Example 1
text: calculate needed sample size two-sample t-test specified power 0.8, significance level 0.05, effect size 0.4, can use pwr.t.test function R. ’s can :

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.3 effect size = 0.40
code:
library(pwr)
pwr.t.test(n=NULL,
           d = 0.4,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = 0.80, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")## 
##      Two-sample t test power calculation 
## 
##               n = 99.08032
##               d = 0.4
##       sig.level = 0.05
##           power = 0.8
##     alternative = two.sided
## 
## NOTE: n is number in *each* group

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.5 R Code Example 2
text: Illustrate influence sample size p-value test.fundamental observation sample size increases, higher probability obtaining smaller p-value, assuming predetermined effect size.

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.6 Sample size = 200
code:
# Set the seed for reproducibility
set.seed(123)

# Specify parameters
n1 <- 100  # Sample size for group 1
n2 <- 100  # Sample size for group 2
mean_diff <- 4  # Desired mean difference between groups
sd <- 10  # Common standard deviation for both groups

# Generate random samples for two groups
group1 <- rnorm(n1, mean = 0, sd = sd)
group2 <- rnorm(n2, mean = mean_diff, sd = sd)

# Perform a two-sample t-test
t.test(group1, group2)## 
##  Welch Two Sample t-test
## 
## data:  group1 and group2
## t = -1.5194, df = 197.35, p-value = 0.1303
## alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
## 95 percent confidence interval:
##  -4.6428618  0.6019159
## sample estimates:
## mean of x mean of y 
## 0.9040591 2.9245320

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.7 Sample size = 240
code:
# Set the seed for reproducibility
set.seed(123)

# Specify parameters
n1 <- 120  # Sample size for group 1
n2 <- 120  # Sample size for group 2
mean_diff <- 4  # Desired mean difference between groups
sd <- 10  # Common standard deviation for both groups

# Generate random samples for two groups
group1 <- rnorm(n1, mean = 0, sd = sd)
group2 <- rnorm(n2, mean = mean_diff, sd = sd)

# Perform a two-sample t-test
t.test(group1, group2)## 
##  Welch Two Sample t-test
## 
## data:  group1 and group2
## t = -2.9529, df = 235.89, p-value = 0.003466
## alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
## 95 percent confidence interval:
##  -5.974416 -1.192717
## sample estimates:
## mean of x mean of y 
## 0.1544151 3.7379818

chapter: 16 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
heading: 16.8 Effect Size, Sample Size, and Statistical Power
text: \(\alpha\) = probability Type error, known “false positive”\(\beta\) = probability Type II error, known “false negative”\(1-\beta\) also called power, statistical power.basic idea, sample size increases, power also increases.
code:
pwr.t.test(n=100,
           d = 0.3,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = NULL, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")## 
##      Two-sample t test power calculation 
## 
##               n = 100
##               d = 0.3
##       sig.level = 0.05
##           power = 0.5600593
##     alternative = two.sided
## 
## NOTE: n is number in *each* group
pwr.t.test(n=200,
           d = 0.3,
           sig.level = 0.05, 
           power = NULL, 
           type = "two.sample",
           alternative="two.sided")## 
##      Two-sample t test power calculation 
## 
##               n = 200
##               d = 0.3
##       sig.level = 0.05
##           power = 0.8491491
##     alternative = two.sided
## 
## NOTE: n is number in *each* group
